name: Fontaine–Mazur conjecture
summary: The Fontaine–Mazur conjecture proposes that "purely arithmetic" \(p\)-adic representations of a number field's Galois group must come from algebraic geometry, such as the étale cohomology of varieties. In simpler terms, it conjectures that any \(p\)-adic Galois representation that is unramified outside a finite set of primes and "potentially semi-stable" arises from the geometry of an algebraic variety. The conjecture also includes a related statement that there are no infinite unramified extensions of a number field whose Galois group is a pro-\(p\) group.
head: Conditions for the Galois representation Almost everywhere unramified: The representation is unramified outside a finite set of primes. Potentially semi-stable at p: Its restriction to the decomposition group at a prime \(p\) is potentially semi-stable. This is now understood to be equivalent to being de Rham at \(p\).
tail: Conclusion from algebraic geometry Comes from geometry: The representation is a subquotient of the \(\ell \)-adic cohomology of some algebraic variety over the number field (up to a Tate twist).
